skill.name: bash-defensive-patterns
skill.description: Master defensive Bash programming techniques for production-grade scripts. Use when writing robust shell scripts, CI/CD pipelines, or system utilities requiring fault tolerance and safety.
skill.summary: Master defensive Bash programming techniques for production-grade scripts. Use when writing robust s...

security_audit.summary: No data theft, exfiltration, or malicious execution patterns were found. Content is instructional and matches its stated purpose.

content.value_statement: Write Bash scripts that fail safely and are easier to debug. This skill provides defensive patterns for errors, inputs, and cleanup.
actual_capabilities: Shows strict mode setup with error traps
Demonstrates safe variable and array handling
limitations: Does not execute or test scripts for you
Does not provide OS specific installer steps
Does not validate external command versions

use_cases.title: Harden CI scripts
use_cases.description: Apply strict mode, traps, and safe file handling to reduce pipeline failures.

use_cases.title: Safer maintenance scripts
use_cases.description: Build idempotent system scripts with logging and cleanup patterns.

use_cases.title: Reliable utilities
use_cases.description: Add input validation and dry run support to team utilities.

prompt_templates.title: Strict mode setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Start a new Bash script safely
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Bash script header with strict mode, error traps, and a cleanup handler for temporary files.

prompt_templates.title: Parse arguments
prompt_templates.scenario: Add CLI options to a script
prompt_templates.prompt: Show a robust argument parser with --verbose, --dry-run, and --output, plus validation.

prompt_templates.title: Safe file ops
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide safe move and safe delete functions with clear error messages.

prompt_templates.title: Process orchestration
prompt_templates.prompt: Give a pattern to start background jobs, track PIDs, and cleanly stop on SIGTERM.

output_examples.input: Explain how to add strict mode and cleanup to my script
output: Enable strict mode with set -Eeuo pipefail
Add an ERR trap that prints the failing line
Create a temp directory with mktemp -d
Use an EXIT trap to remove the temp directory

best_practices: Enable strict mode and inherit ERR traps
Quote all variables and validate inputs
Use traps for cleanup and clear error messages
anti_patterns: Using unquoted variables in file operations

faq.question: Is this compatible with macOS and Linux?
faq.answer: Yes, examples target Bash on common macOS and Linux environments.

faq.question: Does it support POSIX sh?
faq.answer: No, many examples use Bash specific features.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into CI pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, the patterns are designed for CI and automation scripts.

faq.question: Does it access my files or secrets?
faq.answer: No, it only provides guidance and code patterns.

faq.question: What if strict mode breaks my script?
faq.answer: Review unset variables and failing commands, then add checks or defaults.

faq.question: How does this compare to a linter?
faq.answer: It provides patterns and examples, not automated linting.
